instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message: Hello. Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board here with liquid spill. Originally liquid was near <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> and C10G1. I cleaned everything, gave a nice reflow with lots of Amtech flux on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> and still cannot get charger to negotiate 20V. Both ports give 5V stuck. <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> is responsible for RTC, but there are no shorts near it nor anywhere on the board. Where to start? I have very little experience with these new boards with USB-C charging, trying to understand it's architecture, but I'm not very smart LOL.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Any voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message:
Do you get now <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>?
Also check all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages.
If present, then see if machine is detected in DFU mode.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground at L6900.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message:
Then post <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> voltages.
And diode mode to ground at <CAPACITOR>C6907</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>-13 and their traces.
Be sure to have good solders/traces for <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>; you may need to replace it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message: Verified resistors and traces and all seems normal... Probably chip gone bad because of corrosion. Will need to order from China as I don't have any donor boards here.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message: Hello! Just posting feedback here. I ordered the chip from AliExpress. Replaced it and now the board works again! Thanks AGAIN for all the help. You are the man! Whenever I go to Madrid I'm gonna pay you a couple of beers. Thanks one more time.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message: i have this same model and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5v at .25a. I have all of the voltages that are mentioned in this post

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Minor Liquid Damage 5V on charger
threads.message:
Try revive option in DFU.
If doesn't help, open new thread with your board...
